Context: The text provides information about a supply chain and operations management advanced diploma program offered by the Centre for Business at George Brown College. This program is part of the School of Management and requires completion of two semesters of work experience to graduate, which can be co-op (paid) or internship (unpaid). The text mentions that fourteen programs at the Centre for Business have earned accreditation from the Accreditation Council for Business Schools and Programs (ACBSP). The names of the schools offering these accredited programs are Accounting and Finance, Human Resources, Management, Marketing, and the Honours Bachelor of Commerce (Financial Services) program at the School of Accounting and Finance. George Brown is one of only two colleges in Ontario to have earned ACBSP accreditation.
file_path: scraped_pages/programpages2024/Business Administration – Supply Chain and Operations Management Program (with work experience) B162 | George Brown College2024.txt

Context: The George Brown College offers a Business Administration – Supply Chain and Operations Management program in partnership with SCMAO (Supply Chain Management Association Ontario). This program provides students with the opportunity to fast track into the CSCMP (Certified Supply Chain Management Professional) Designation program. To graduate from the B162 program, one needs to complete 38 courses: 35 mandatory courses, 3 General Education electives, and 2 Work Experience terms. Some students may be required to take COMM 1000 (Introduction to College Communication) or MATH 1027 (Business Math with Remediation) before progressing to other courses, but these do not count toward the 37 courses required for graduation and will incur additional charges. Students must also complete three General Education courses during semesters 4, 5, and 6.
file_path: scraped_pages/programpages2024/Business Administration – Supply Chain and Operations Management Program (with work experience) B162 | George Brown College2024.txt

Context:
To graduate from the college, students must complete three General Education courses from at least two of the following categories: Social Sciences (GSSC), Arts and Humanities (GHUM), or Science and Technology (GSCI). Students are required to make up any failed or dropped courses before graduation.

Students can make up these classes during the day, and some are offered in the evening through Continuing Education. It is important for students to check with the business office staff to ensure that Continuing Education courses are equivalent to what is taught in the full-time program. Some courses may not be offered in every semester, and staff can assist students with any special timetable requirements they may have.

The text provides information on courses offered in Semesters 1, 2, and 3. Each semester has a list of codes, courses, and their respective prerequisites. For example, in Semester 1, students can take BUS 1038 - Business Concepts I which has no prerequisite. In Semester 2, students can take MGMT 4009 - Operations Management which requires a pre-requisite of MATH 1008.

The following is a list of courses with their respective semesters and prerequisites:

Semester 1:
- BUS 1038 - Business Concepts I (NONE)
- COMM 2000 - Communicating Across Contexts (NONE)
- COMP 1010 - Business Computer Applications I (NONE)
- MARK 1020 - Principles of Marketing I (NONE)
- MARK 1049 - Supply Chain Management 1 (NONE)
- MATH 1008 - Math for Business & Management I (NONE)

Semester 2:
- ECON 1031 - Microeconomics (NONE)
- BUS 1040 - Project Management (NONE)
- COMM 1034 - Professional Communications I (COMM 2000)
- COMP 1115 - Business Computer Applications II (COMP 1010)
- MATH 1095 - Math for Business & Management II (MATH 1008)
- MGMT 4009 - Operations Management (MATH 1008)

Semester 3:
- PSY 1129 - Organizational Behaviour (NONE)
- MGMT 2049 - Supply Chain Management II (MGMT 4009 & COMP 1115)
- STAT 1012 - Business Statistics (MATH 1095)
- ACCT 1036 - Principles of Accounting (NONE)
- BUS 1044 - Business Law (NONE)
- ECON 1032 - Macroeconomics (NONE)
- BUS 1000 - Work Experience Prep Course* (COMM 1007 & 3.0 GPA)

Students taking the Work Experience Option are mandated to take this course, which requires a prerequisite of COMM 1007 and a minimum 3.0 GPA.

There is no explicit mention of the specific program offered by the college in the provided text.

Context:
The text provides information about various courses offered in different semesters as part of a management program at the college. Here is the extracted information:

Semester 5:
- Course: MGMT 2051 (Transportation and Warehousing)
- Course: MGMT 3015 (Quality Improvement Lean/Six Sigma)
- Course: STS 1037 (Career Planning & Development)
- General Education Elective: Select One
- Prerequisite: NONE for some courses, others have specific course codes mentioned

Semester 6:
- Course: MGMT 3027 (Integrated Supply Chain Management)
- Course: MGMT 3049
- Course: MGMT 1030 (Enterprise Resource Planning)
- Course: MGMT 2049
- Course: MGMT 3006 (Strategic Analysis)
- Course: MGMT 3037 (Supply Chain and Technology)
- General Education Elective: Select One

Additionally, the text mentions several program learning outcomes for the management graduates. These include:

1. Examine the connections between strategic objectives, stakeholder expectations, and supply chain functions, processes, and roles to support decision-making, problem-solving, and coordination of tasks.
2. Determine the value added and financial implications of supply chain decisions on overall business profitability, efficiency, and stakeholder satisfaction.
3. Ensure supply chain activities and transactions are compliant with relevant legal, regulatory, contractual obligations, industry and organization standards and policies for quality, health, safety, accountability, social, and environmental responsibility.
4. Use risk-mitigation tools and strategies to inform supply chain management decisions.
5. Manage the acquisition and sale of goods, services, and materials in accordance with best practices and public and private sector stakeholder expectations across a variety of industries.
6. Plan and schedule material requirements and resource allocation and manage inventories for efficient production and fulfillment of customer orders and returns.
7. Manage the efficient handling and transportation of goods.

Context:
Program Information:
- The text mentions that the person will be managing inventories for efficient production and fulfillment of customer orders and returns.
- They will contribute to the identification and management of continuous improvements to functions and processes within and between supply chains.
- Technologies will be used to enhance work performance and support supply chain functions, processes, transactions and communications.
- Relevant trends, emerging technologies, economic, political and environmental issues will be monitored to enhance work performance and guide management decisions.
- The person is expected to maintain relationships with a diversity of stakeholders to support business goals.
- Application for personal, career and professional development is encouraged.

Financial Information:
- Domestic tuition for the first two semesters of programs starting in Fall 2023 is $3,776.00.
- International tuition for the first two semesters of programs starting in Fall 2023 is $17,925.00.
- Tuition fees are subject to board approval and material, student service and ancillary fees are estimated based on prior years.
- All fees are subject to change without notice and do not include books which are purchased separately.
- The tuition fee for this program does NOT include the cost of work experience semesters. There is an additional fee of $500 for each work experience semester.
- Financial assistance is available through OSAP for applicants who meet eligibility criteria.

Program Details:
- The program includes two work experience semesters.
- International Students are advised to visit the International Fees and Related Costs page for more information.

Context:
To apply for George Brown College as a domestic student, applicants need an Ontario Secondary School Diploma or equivalent, with a grade 12 English (C or U) and either a grade 11 Math (C, M or U) or grade 12 (C or U). Mature students (19 years of age or older and no OSSD) can take the Admissions Assessment for English and Math or consider upgrading to achieve the required credits. Minimum requirements do not guarantee admission to a program. Course exemptions are available for some college and university credits, which can be checked on the George Brown College website. Proficiency in English communications is necessary for success in the program.

International students should apply through the George Brown College Online Application System. They should also visit the International Admissions page for country-specific admission requirements. Information sessions are held regularly, where applicants can have their questions answered and learn about program content and career options. For inquiries about admissions, international students can contact international recruitment representatives specialized by country of origin.

Applicants with financial inquiries, such as OSAP, Bursaries, or Scholarships, should contact the Admissions Office at [admissions@georgebrown.ca](mailto:admissions@georgebrown.ca) or visit the Admissions section. The exact information about fees is not mentioned in the text.

There are no specified deadlines for applications provided in the text. However, it is mentioned that international students should apply through the George Brown College Online Application System and visit the How to Apply page for more information on how and when to apply.

Contact information for specific inquiries:

* Domestic student admissions: [admissions@georgebrown.ca](mailto:admissions@georgebrown.ca) or Admissions section
* International student admissions: Book a virtual meeting or submit an inquiry through the International Contact Us page.
